author: KennethHoff
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

I am trying to add Aspire to an existing project and, due to the amount of dependencies, restarting Aspire after every change is unacceptable. We have found out that "stop the project in Aspire, manually run `dotnet build`, and then start the project" works like a charm, but that workflow is very tedious and up to >10x increase in restart time, compared to a simple command 

What I want is to be able to do something like `aspire stop "web-api" && dotnet build --project <PathToProject> && aspire start "web-api".

### Describe the solution you'd like

Introduce a new `dotnet aspire` CLI tool that gives the developer full access to the AppHost. The following commands would be a good start: 

1. `aspire start <ResourceName>`; Starts a resource by name. 
2. `aspire stop <ResourceName>`; Stops a resource by name. 
3. `aspire log <ResourceName>`; Prints the X most recent lines from the console log.
4. `aspire log tail <ResourceName>`; Same as above, but tailing.
5. `aspire command <ResourceName> <CommandName>`; Runs a specified command on a specified resource.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body: @davidfowl is this something that will be improved with dotnet watch support? @KennethHoff can you confirm if you are using Visual Studio to run your application?

nodes.author: KennethHoff
nodes.body: @joperezr I am using JetBrains Rider and/or Neovim on a Macbook (Pro M3); Running Aspire exclusively through `dotnet run --project ...` from the CLI

nodes.author: KennethHoff
nodes.body: To be clear, while support for `dotnet watch` would help _a lot_ - removing the primary motivator for this feature - I would still really like being able to execute custom commands and read logs from the CLI (The terminal is just a generally superior interface for reading and manipulating text)

title: Full access to Aspire from the Command Line

author: mitchdenny
body:
At the moment with the `aspire add` command we don't really give anyone next steps once they have installed a package. So folks may not necessarily know that they need to jump in and update `Program.cs` to make use of the hosting integration.

I think we should point people at some docs specific to each package. It might make sense to point at the `README.md` file on NuGet if we know that the package source was NuGet.

Example output:

```bash
aspire add redis
The Aspire.Hosting.Redis@9.2.0-dev package was installed.
View the README.md at https://www.nuget.org/packages/Aspire.Hosting.Redis/9.0.0
```

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: @maddymontaquila thoughts on this?

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body:
> @maddymontaquila thoughts on this?

oooo i like this. we could also give them the option to stick it in their app host for them if we wanted to get fancy. Or spit out sample code - ie
```
Successfully added Aspire.Hosting.Redis. To add to your app:

builder.AddRedis("name")

Learn more (docs link)
```

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: Moving to 9.3.

title: `aspire add` should give next steps when package is installed.

This is expected. What `aspire add` does is add the hosting integration to the AppHost, but it doesn't update the code to do it, you need to manually go in and add the code:

```csharp
builder.AddRedis("cache");
```

nodes.author: mitchdenny

@maddymontaquila even though this is currently by design I do think it will be confusing to folks so I think in the near term (9.3?) we probably want to automatically add in the code.

The challenge is figuring out what the code should be in the first place. Perhaps the best we can do for 9.2 is point to the README, so a dupe of #8159

author: captainsafia

### Is there an existing issue for this?

### Describe the bug

When calling `aspire add` in a non-AppHost project, the tool will install only the hosting integration.

### Expected Behavior

The tool should be able to detect if it is being invoked in an AppHost or non-AppHost project and insert the client integration or hosting integration appropriately.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
In both the case of hosting and client integrations this would involve reading the Program.cs file and injecting the code in the right place. However, this is hugely dependent on people who structure their codebases - show we only work in the happy path and error out if we are unable to make the right edits?

We also need to consider what we would do in non-.NET projects where we don't have any client integrations necessarily.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I don't think this issue includes injecting code. It's about showing client integrations when the detected project type isn't an app host.

author: mitchdenny
body:
When running `aspire` commands there are several times where we implicitly or explicitly run a build. However when doing things like running publish mutiple times in a row we don't really need to perform a build again - we just need to run the apphost.

We should try to detect when this is the case and then do a `run --no-build` to help improve the startup time for publish and run scenarios.

author: mitchdenny
body:
We are considering introducing a feature to the CLI where from the command-prompt you can interrogate a running app host to get values to support running other commands on the command-line.

We might have something like this:

```bash
aspire get-cs mydb
stdout: <connectionstring>
```

The way this would work is that when the apphost is launched we would determine the unix path that the apphost is listening on for a connection deterministically based on the apphost path.

The `aspire get-cs` command would find the apphost the same way that `aspire run` does (based on working directory context and `.aspire/settings.json`.

Once the apphost and live unix socket path is detected the apphost could be connected to and interrogated. We'd probably have to have mechanisms in the design to wait until the apphost was healthy.

We may wish to introduce an annotation with a callback into the app model which represents a value that can be queried for each resource. So you might end up with something like:

```csharp
builder.AddResource(...)
       .WithGetCallback("connectionString", (...) => {});
```

That way developers designing resources could specifically expose additional values if they chose to (e.g. output values from azure provisioner deployments).

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: /cc @davidfowl @maddymontaquila

nodes.author: codymullins
nodes.body:
+1 here, this is useful for a variety of things in the local dev cycle:

1. Allow running database operations from the cli, e.g. ef migrations, sqlcmd
2. Allow querying local or remote redis clusters from the cli
3. Allow running commands, i.e. to nats-server, rabbitmq, etc

Being able to rely on the connection strings for these or secrets in a single place is very useful.

author: mitchdenny
body:
The CLI breaks when you are using authenticated feeds. This problem has layers. The Aspire CLI shells out to `dotnet new`. But it doesn't support interactive auth flows (the auth flow only comes into play with `dotnet restore`. But even if we did that we would need to figure out how we want to present that in the CLI.

What we really need is some kind of preauth mechanism.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: /cc @baronfel interested in your thoughts here.

title: `aspire` CLI and NuGet authentication scenarios

author: IEvangelist
body:
There's a lot of design decisions that need to be discussed as it relates to forwarding CLI arguments from `aspire new` to the `dotnet new`. For example, this command isn't supported:

```
aspire new aspire-starter -n AspireApp -o AspireApp --use-redis-cache
```

Nor is this command:

```
aspire new aspire-starter -n AspireApp -o AspireApp -- --use-redis-cache
```

One might assume that they could pass arguments that are known to be dotnet template args, but that's not the case. Should we prompt in the CLI for these values? Or should we just forward unmatched args to the underlying command?
title: Aspire CLI: new command arg forwarding

```
$env:VAR1=LARGE_VALUE
```

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @mitchdenny

title: Aspire CLI --watch large environment variables

author: maddymontaquila
body: I think we should expand the aspire add command to show tags for the packages - and also make it searchable for that. The reason I want this is cause I keep typing "Vite" in when I want to add the NodeJS extensions toolkit package - npm, node, pnpm, vite, are all valid tags on nuget for it so that would really help my searching https://www.nuget.org/packages/CommunityToolkit.Aspire.Hosting.NodeJS.Extensions/9.4.1-beta.291

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: This might be unreliable. NuGet org supports searching via tags, but other registries don't typically (e.g. AzDO feeds). We can optimize the Nuget.org experience provided it doesn't stop the private feeds experience working. Private feeds working is critical for enterprise scenarios where you have supply chain security requirements.

title: Aspire CLI - show tags on aspire add

author: radical
body:
This is the tracking issue for all of the different things we need to do for bundling and acquiring the Aspire CLI in 9.4. All individual tasks will be attached to this tracking issue as sub-issues.

cc @joperezr
title: [CI] CLI tool bundling tasks

author: davidfowl
body:
Any errors that come from dcp or the apphost itself don't show up when using aspire run. This makes it really hard to diagnose problems (we hit this on the live stream with port conflicts).

Generally, we need a first-class way to capture logs from the app host without parsing the console output.  I think that means a custom logger provider that writes logs to the back channel in a structured way so that the cli can build custom rendering on top.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
I agree we need to do something (I watched the video where you guys tackled Bitwarden). It should be straight forward to pull logs across the back channel for the apphost.


The real question is one of visual presentation.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Other thought was we add the app host to the dashboard itself, e.g. as a pseudo resource. That way you could see its console logs and if we hooked up OTel to it could get all that goodness too.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: New approach #9990

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Note that this is an issue in the non-CLI scenarios too, e.g. when launched from VS. The dashboard is popped open in a browser and folks don't know to look in the popped terminal to see AppHost logs.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: So we've merged in the change to the CLI so it now outputs a link to the logs so that if there are DCP errors etc it will be available there. Do we want to try and make the AppHost show up as a resource in 9.4?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
>Do we want to try and make the AppHost show up as a resource in 9.4?

I think we need to try and do something, yeah. Do we have consensus on the approach of the AppHost being a pseudo-resource?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: No, I think @danegsta updated DCP to make it so that we can discovery what logs are for which resource? If so, we can route errors to the console using the resource logger.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
I think provided we can launch he dashboard that gives us what we want (routing DCP errors to the resource via the resource logger).

Far easier than trying to parse it out of a single log anyway.

If the dashboard fails to launch then the app host logs will show that pretty clearly.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> Far easier than trying to parse it out of a single log anyway.

We already parse it them. This is about pushing resource specific DCP errors to the per resource logs as well.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
mitchdenny
nodes.body: I've been looking at this. I think we'll need to punt the routing of DCP reconciler errors to the resource logger, we'll need to come up with a better way of identifying which log line is associated with a resource (if any). It'll probably need to be a DCP side change followed by some tweaks to the parsing logic in `GetLogInfo(...)`.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
We have an issue about this on the DCP side https://github.com/microsoft/usvc/issues/219 the idea being that you can ask for "all DCP logs (errors and warnings) that are relevant for specific resource". This would come as a separate log stream, but you could combine it with the regular logs from the resource in the CLI/dashboard.

I do not think trying to parse all DCP logs yourself will set you up for success. They contain a lot of internal diagnostics stuff and we make zero guarantees about them being the same from release to release.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @danegsta punt to next version?

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
> [@danegsta](https://github.com/danegsta) punt to next version?

Yeah, we've got the new log sources in DCP, but need to figure out the best way to integrate them into the existing logging experience in the dashboard (and CLI).

title: Error logs output from the apphost and dcp don't show up during `aspire run`

author: aradalvand
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Add some way to see resource logs (most importantly, project logs) from within the terminal as opposed to Aspire's web UI.
This is a very strong preference for a lot of people (including myself). The native terminal can be customized in ways that the Aspire web "console" can't, and you might just be very used to interacting with the terminal rather than just clicking buttons in a GUI. In general, any development tool that is serious enough almost invariably has deep CLI support; so should Aspire.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Introduce an `aspire attach <resource-name>` command as part of the Aspire CLI, allowing the user to see a resource (or at the very least a project's) logs through the console/terminal, just in the same way that they would if they had run the project directly using `dotnet run --project <resource-project-path>`.

Additionally, a compound command like `aspire run attach <resource name>` which takes care of both 1. running the Aspire host 2. then immediately attaching the shell to the specified resource's console, would be very useful.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: xamir82
nodes.body: Seconded. Running commands is just fundamentally a much faster interaction mechanism than using a UI.

nodes.author: KennethHoff
nodes.body: Duplicates https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/6854

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body:
We experimented with showing logs or having a gesture to show logs in the CLI but the rendering bug tail was huge. I totally agree that I'd love to see the logs in the CLI too. Won't happen in the short term but definitely important to solve once the CLI goes GA - we spiked building a TUI so that we could make this work but then we'd have to build and maintain a TUI framework that has what we need (existing ones don't yet) lol. 

we are also considering `aspire run [resourcename]` for the future and maybe that we default to showing you all the logs for that specific resource.

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body: cc @mitchdenny in case you havent seen this and want to weigh in - and cc @DeagleGross because this might come up wrt `exec` eventually

nodes.author: KennethHoff
nodes.body: A TUI would be fantastic. Something like tmux and mprocs would be great

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
Effectively what this would be is doing pass thru (mostly) of the input and output streams.

I'd prefer to see us add interactive terminal support in the dashboard first to be honest.

nodes.author: aradalvand
nodes.body:
> I totally agree that I'd love to see the logs in the CLI too. Won't happen in the short term but definitely important to solve once the CLI goes GA - we spiked building a TUI so that we could make this work but then we'd have to build and maintain a TUI framework that has what we need (existing ones don't yet) lol.

Wouldn't implementing a simple pass-through mechanism for logs be sufficient for that specific use case?

title: Add support for terminal-based console

author: captainsafia
body: The `PublishCommandBase` currently implements an event-loop to process RPC messages from the AppHost to the CLI when processing steps/tasks emitted by the AppHost. We need a similar event-loop to process RPC messages from the AppHost that support the prompting functionality. For prompting, we need to expand this behavior to commands that are not `publish`/`deploy`.  We should consider centralizing the event loop that manages request/response-based patterns from the AppHost so that all CLI commands can hook into it.
title: Centralize UI event loop for Aspire CLI

author: captainsafia
body:
The `InteractionService` currently models requests for confirmation as `MessageBoxInteractions`.

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/6ab1e17a1888f3e0b3ebbbd83269088d824e1baf/src/Aspire.Hosting/ApplicationModel/InteractionService.cs#L36-L44

We should consider modeling confirmation as an `InputInteraction` and add confirmation to the `InputType` enum to make the implementation play more nicely with CLI-based UIs where both confirmations and text-based inputs flow through the same pipeline.

Related to this, we should consider renaming certain APIs (like `InputsDialogInteractionOptions`) to remove assumptions about the type of UI that is used to present an interaction.

cc: @JamesNK @mitchdenny

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
The CLI backend channel would just subscribe to the watch method on InteractionService. It can then send the data to the CLI however it wants.

In the dashboard a confirmation, and an input of type checkbox are very different.

Also, multiple inputs can be sent at once. It wouldn't make sense to have multiple confirmations in a dialog.

nodes.author: JamesNK
nodes.body:
> Related to this, we should consider renaming certain APIs (like InputsDialogInteractionOptions) to remove assumptions about the type of UI that is used to present an interaction.

What should be renamed? Change Select to Choice? Or Checkbox to Boolean?

nodes.author: captainsafia
nodes.body:
> The CLI backend channel would just subscribe to the watch method on InteractionService. It can then send the data to the CLI however it wants.

Yep, we can adapt the MessageBoxConfirmation in the CLI layer to the a confirmation prompt. However, it felt like a bit of a code smell to me to have two different conceptual types for the same semantic concept (Yes/No). Unifying it under the `InputType` umbrella would also make the make projection that we have to do in the CLI a bit easier. We can always assume that the Interaction is an InputInteraction and rely on the types to disambiguate between the types of prompts.

> In the dashboard a confirmation, and an input of type checkbox are very different.

Yep, I think this gets at my concern around the InteractionService being overfit for the way the dashboard models UI. A confirmation and a checkbox are visually different things in the dashboard but semantically I think they represent the same type of interaction: an input interaction that returns a boolean.

> Also, multiple inputs can be sent at once. It wouldn't make sense to have multiple confirmations in a dialog.

Yep, agree this makes sense for the dashboard. The CLI has the opposite pattern though: you can only ever prompt for a single input at a time.

I haven't dived too much into the Dashboard implementation but I assume that if you modeled confirmation as an InputInteraction you can always constrain that only a single InputInteraction is sent when you prompt for confirmation?

> What should be renamed? Change Select to Choice? Or Checkbox to Boolean?

Yep, strawman for how the `InputType` enum can be renamed to be less tied to the values that you can provide as a `<input type>`:

```
public enum InputType
{
    String,
    SecretString,
    Choice,
    Boolean,
    Number
}
```

In this case, we might have to model whether an InputType.Boolean is a Checkbox or a Confirm separately in the implementation, hopefully somewhere that is Dashboard specific. The existing MessageIntent might help here?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @JamesNK take a look at the cli implementation

title: InteractionService should expose `InteractionInput`-based APIs for requesting confirmation

author: jguadagno
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Working with a `Program.cs` that has a try/catch block in it where the `builder` object is built, the current Aspire templates place the `builder.AddServiceDefaults()` and the `builder.MapDefaultEndpoints()` outside the try/catch block causing the application to no longer compile.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect that the Aspire template detect the `builder` is being created inside a try/catch block and implement the required Aspire methods in the same block.

### Steps To Reproduce

My public repo of [contacts-noauth](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth) is the starter point for this bug.  Using Visual Studio, add .NET Aspire Orchestration to the *Contacts.Api* project. It will work and create the *AppHost* and *ServiceDefaults* project, however, the project *Contacts.Api* will no longer compile.

If you look at [Program.cs](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/main/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs) you will notice there is a try block that starts on line [18](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/b91f0ecb201f4f9a52e9b504d5dc36b43617173b/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs#L18). The builder is created on line 20.  However, when running the Aspire .NET Orchestration adds the following lines

```csharp
builder.AddServiceDefaults();

builder.MapDefaultEndpoints();
```

to lines 49 and 51, outside the try/catch block where the `builder` object is not available.


### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

author: DamianEdwards
body:
Add support for executing commands in container resources, i.e. equivalent of `docker exec`.

## In the dashboard

All container resources get a new command like "Execute command..." that when selected pops a dialog using the interaction service that prompts for the command to execute (required) and the working directory in the container to execute it in (optional, defaults to root). Once accepted the command is executed in the resource's container (via existing DCP exec functionality that needs to be hooked up to `Aspire.Hosting` I believe). Logs from the execution should be output to the resource's logs.

The command should only be enabled when the container is running (unhealthy is fine).

It would be great if we could auto-navigate to the resource logs page once the command prompt is submitted so that the execution and output of the command is immediately visible to the user.

## In `Aspire.Hosting`

A new API is added to allow easily adding a pre-defined exec command to any container resource:

```csharp
builder.AddContainer("mycontainer",
    .WithExecCommand("sh -c \"hello from inside the container!\"", "Echo hello");
```

It should be based on the API signature of the `WithCommand` and `WithHttpCommand` methods, accepting required info as parameters and then a `CommandOptions` or if suitable a custom derived `ExecCommandOptions` for all the other info (icon, etc.), e.g.:

```csharp
public static IResourceBuilder<T> WithExecCommand<T>(this IResourceBuilder builder, string command, string displayName, string? workingDir = null, string? commandName = null, ExecCommandOptions? commandOptions = null)
    where T : ContainerResource;
```

Additionally, an API that exposes the actual capability to perform the container exec should be publicly available so that any custom command or code otherwise running in the AppHost can perform a container exec when it needs to, e.g. `ContainerExecService`.

## In the `aspire` CLI

The Aspire CLI's `exec` command will be updated to support executing commands in containers. This should feel similar to using the `exec` command for executing a command in the context of a project resource, but this time rather than simply getting the configuration of the resource applied to the command, the command itself will be executed inside the container:

```
$ aspire exec --resource mycontainer sh -c "hello from inside the container!"
```

The command should start the AppHost, ensure the target container resource is running (along with all of its dependencies) before executing the command and streaming the output back to the terminal, and exit using the exit code of the command inside the container.

It should be possible to set the working directory inside the container via a `-w/--workdir` option, e.g.:

```
$ aspire exec --resource mycontainer --workdir /some/dir ls -r
```

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: There are [types for the DCP container exec feature](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/src/Aspire.Hosting/Dcp/Model/ContainerExec.cs) in Aspire.Hosting, so it should be possible to start integrating them into a `WithExecCommand` API right away.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: We want this outside of exec as an API so that it can be done via a command as well

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
>We want this outside of exec as an API so that it can be done via a command as well
 
So you want an API in `Aspire.Hosting` that separate from the proposed `WithExecCommand` so that any custom command (or anything else for that matter) can perform a container exec when it wants, right?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Correct! I think the thing we’re missing today that everyone wants is the ability to run an executable or a “command” inside the container or on the host “against a resource”. I’m still not clear on what that looks like but there are issues and discussions that describe some scenarios

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: This is going to bump into users’ desire for stdio/terminal access too. Someone is going to want to run /bin/bash in their container to troubleshoot an issue.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
>This is going to bump into users’ desire for stdio/terminal access too. Someone is going to want to run /bin/bash in their container to troubleshoot an issue.

Yep but let's crawl first 😁

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: Chatting to @DeagleGross about this and I agree with @davidfowl about the need to expose an API here that will allow folks to invoke commands in a container from anywhere in a hosting integration. WithExecCommand(...) would use that interface under the covers, but I could see myself using it in a few different ways as well.

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Because `Aspire.Cli.Tests` tests project references both `Aspire.Hosting` and `Aspire.Cli`, and `InternalsVisibleTo` is enabled on both to `Aspire.Cli.Tests`, any internal types have conflicts with "Type exists in both XXX and YYY".

This prevents sharing internal code between the two.

### Expected Behavior

I think `Aspire.Hosting` and `Aspire.Hosting.Testing` shouldn't be referenced by `Aspire.Cli.Tests`.

If there are tests that need both then I argue that is an integration test, and should be moved to a new integration tests project, i.e. `Aspire.Cli.IntegrationTests`.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

author: captainsafia
body:
### Root cause

`PublishCommandBase.HandlePromptActivityAsync` builds the prompt text like so:

```
var promptText = inputs.Count > 1
    ? $"{input.Label}: "
    : $"[bold]{activity.Data.StatusText}[/]";
```

* For **multi-input** prompts (`inputs.Count > 1`) the label is displayed (`input.Label`).
* For a **single** input the label is ignored, and only `StatusText` is shown.

Because `PublishingActivityReporter` uses `StatusText` for narrative context (e.g., *“Configure deployment target”*), not for the field label, the prompt becomes ambiguous.

---

### Proposed fix

1. **Always** prefer `input.Label` when it is provided, even for single inputs.  
2. For single-input prompts, prepend the bold header (`StatusText`) **only when it is different from the label**, avoiding duplication.  
3. Escape Spectre.Console markup in both `StatusText` and `Label`.  

Illustrative helper:

```csharp
private static string BuildPromptText(
    PublishingPromptInput input,
    int inputCount,
    string statusText)
{
    if (inputCount > 1)
        return $"{input.Label.EscapeMarkup()}: ";

    // Single-input path
    var header = statusText ?? string.Empty;
    var label  = input.Label ?? string.Empty;

    if (header.Equals(label, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase))
        return $"{label.EscapeMarkup()}: ";

    return $"[bold]{header.EscapeMarkup()}[/] {label.EscapeMarkup()}: ";
}
```

---

### Acceptance criteria

- [ ] A single-input prompt displays **both** context (`StatusText`) *and* the field label (`Label`), formatted as:  
  `<StatusText> <Label>:` separated by a new line
- [ ] If `StatusText` equals `Label`, the prompt shows **only** the label once.
- [ ] Multi-input prompts remain unchanged.
- [ ] Unit tests cover: single input, multi input, `StatusText` = `Label`, and Spectre markup escaping.

---

### Tasks

- [ ] Update `PublishCommandBase.HandlePromptActivityAsync` (or extract a helper) with the logic above.
- [ ] Add/adjust unit tests in `Aspire.Cli.Tests` verifying correct console output.
- [ ] Run `dotnet test` and ensure all publishing CLI tests pass.
- [ ] (Optional) document the prompt behavior in the publishing CLI README.
title: Labels not properly show for PromptInputsAsync call with single InteractionInput in CLI

author: adegeo
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

The `aspire config *` commands support different levels of global support.

`config get | list` don't support the `-g` flag.
`config set | delete` do support the `-g` flag.

### Expected Behavior

This is confusing for a user because they have to manage their context via the current directory, to handle global config. If I'm curious if setting `xyz` is set globally, but it's already set locally, I cannot see what the global value is if I run `aspire config get xyz`. Further, I don't even know that it gave me that setting via a local override. I have to go back one directory where there isn't a local config file and run the command again to actually see the global value.

Now I understand you want a good user experience or API experience where something gets the value regardless of local or global. I suggest a new command for that `aspire config read` where this command does the smart logic of finding the config value regardless of local or global context.

The `aspire config list` command operates in the same "smart" mode but I don't know where those options are coming from in the results. Perhaps a new command `aspire config listall` or something.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

_No response_

_No response_

author: davidfowl
body:
As a follow-up to #9874, the compatibility error message should be more specific about which component needs to be updated (app host or Aspire CLI) rather than saying "upgrade the app host or aspire cli".

Current Behavior

The error message currently says something like:
> "upgrade the app host or aspire cli"

This is ambiguous and doesn't provide clear guidance on what action to take.

Proposed Improvement

1. Be specific: The error should clearly state which component needs updating based on the actual compatibility issue.

2. Provide actionable commands:
- If it's the app host version that needs updating, show the exact `dotnet add package` command to run
- Example: `dotnet add package Aspire.Hosting --version 9.4.0`

3. Consider automation: Even better, the error could prompt the user asking if they want to automatically update the package, then run the command for them.

Example of improved error messages

When App Host needs updating:

Error: Version mismatch detected.
Your Aspire.Hosting package version (9.3.0) is incompatible with Aspire CLI (9.4.0).

To fix this, run:
  dotnet add package Aspire.Hosting --version 9.4.0

Would you like to run this command now? [Y/n]

When CLI needs updating:

Error: Version mismatch detected.
Your Aspire CLI version (9.3.0) is incompatible with the project's Aspire.Hosting package (9.4.0).

To fix this, update the Aspire CLI:
  dotnet tool update aspire --version 9.4.0

Would you like to run this command now? [Y/n]

Benefits

- Reduces friction for developers
- Clear actionable steps to resolve the issue
- Less time spent figuring out what needs to be updated
- Better developer experience overall
- Consistent with other dotnet tooling that provides fix suggestions

Additional Considerations

- The error handler should detect which component is out of date and provide the appropriate message
- If the user chooses to auto-update, provide clear success/failure feedback
- Consider color coding for better visibility (red for errors, yellow for commands, green for success)

Related Issues

- #9874 - Improve the compatibility error message to include the Aspire.Hosting package version
title: Improve Aspire compatibility error message to be more specific and actionable

author: mitchdenny
body:
Currently, users must manually install the appropriate .NET SDK to use the Aspire CLI effectively. This can cause onboarding friction, especially for new users or those who are unaware of the required SDK version.

# Proposal:
Enhance the Aspire CLI to detect when the required .NET SDK is missing and either:

Prompt the user to install it automatically, or
Offer to download and install the correct SDK version directly through the CLI.
This would streamline the setup process and improve the overall developer experience.

# Benefits:

- Faster onboarding for new users
- Reduces errors caused by SDK version mismatches
- Makes Aspire CLI more user-friendly and accessible

# Additional Context:
Are there technical or security considerations for downloading and installing SDKs programmatically from the CLI? Feedback and suggestions welcome.
title: Automatically install .NET SDK when using Aspire CLI

author: captainsafia
body:
When Docker is not running and `aspire run` is executed, the warning message is buried in log files and requires users to know to check the apphost logs. This makes it difficult to diagnose Docker-related issues quickly.

Navigating to the dashboard shows status that indicates the runtime is unhealthy but doesn't provide an error as clear as what's in the AppHost logs around making sure the runtime is running. Perhaps container runtime issues should be special cases as warning output on the CLI?
title: Docker availability warnings should be more prominent in `aspire run` output

body: ### Is there an existing issue for this? - [x] I have searched the existing issues ### Describe the bug Due to a breaking change in .Net 10, I need to set the `DOTNET_SYSTEM_NET_SECURITY_NOREVOCATIONCHECKBYDEFAULT='true'` for nuget restore to work with .Net 10 (see https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/49785#issuecomment-3139691697 for more details). Whilst this works for .Net build, it doesn't work for `aspire run`. It seems like `aspire run` is not passing the `DOTNET_SYSTEM_NET_SECURITY_NOREVOCATIONCHECKBYDEFAULT` environment variable into the build. `aspire run` continues to fail with the same error as `dotnet build` does when `DOTNET_SYSTEM_NET_SECURITY_NOREVOCATIONCHECKBYDEFAULT` is not set, so it seems like the environment variable is not being flowed through to the app host. ### Expected Behavior `aspire run` should be able to build the project if `dotnet build` / `dotnet run` can ### Steps To Reproduce 1. nodes.author: radical
nodes.body:
This test is failing because `System.NotSupportedException: Cannot show selection prompt since the current terminal isn't interactive.`! I found this in the log for the test suite, but note that this was not captured in the individual tests output.


title: Failing test: Aspire.Cli.Tests.Commands.NewCommandTests.NewCommandDerivesOutputPathFromProjectNameForStarterTemplate

author: davidfowl
body: aspire new aspire add We should clean up how we display these: - We show the feed url and feed name sometimes - The version order is different for add vs new (I think this is a good thing but we should make sure its intentional)
title: Aspire CLI shows versions *and* channels side by side in version selection for aspire new and aspire add

title: Failing test: Aspire.Cli.Tests.Commands.NewCommandTests.NewCommandDoesNotPromptForTemplateVersionIfSpecifiedOnCommandLine

author: davidfowl
body:
The current "aspire update" CLI command only updates a single project's packages. To provide a complete update experience and ensure developer environments are correctly configured, enhance the "aspire update" command to:

- Remove the Aspire workload if present (since the CLI sits outside the workload and should decouple from it)
- Update the Aspire templates installed on the machine to the latest version
- Update the project's Aspire package references and scaffolding (current behavior)

This will allow users to run a single command to bring their machine and project into the right state for Aspire, eliminating duplication/conflicts and simplifying guidance/documentation for upgrades. The command should:
- Be idempotent: safe to run repeatedly
- Report what actions were taken (workload removal, template update, project update)
- Surface actionable errors if steps fail (e.g., workload uninstall issues)

This change will streamline the developer experience and ensure Aspire environments are reliably updated via the CLI.
title: Enhance aspire update command to update Aspire itself and fix developer environment state

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: Did the same thing again and it didn't happen so could be a very subtle timing issue.

title: aspire new triggered ArgumentOutOfRangeException

author: afscrome
body: ### Is there an existing issue for this? - [x] I have searched the existing issues ### Describe the bug I just ran `aspire update` meaning to update update the aspire CLI, however. Realising my mistake, I immediately pressed `ctrl + c` to try and cancel the process, however it took 26 seconds for the cli to actually stop ### Expected Behavior CLI should stop almost instantly after hitting ctrl+c ### Steps To Reproduce 1. Run aspire update in a directory with lots of recursive children. (In my case was `%UserProfile%`). 2. Press ctrl+c ### Exceptions (if any) _No response_ ### .NET Version info ``` aspire --version 9.5.0-preview.1.25460.2+b7914a785128f739a0065144c3e107947f3eef30 ``` ### Anything else? Whilst running this, OneDrive did pop up a load of notifications that it was downloading files, which may have contributed to why the process took so long to complete, although that should be somewhat irrelevant if cancellation was honoured.

nodes.author: MihuBot
nodes.body:
I'm a bot. Here is a possible related and/or duplicate issue (I may be wrong):
- https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/11292

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Can you run with --debug? It might mean we're not flowing the cancellation token properly (we recently updated System.CommandLine).

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Seems to be some element of timing.  If I press ctrl+c in the first few seconds, it doesn't take effect.  But if I press `ctrl+c` repeatedly, the cli will cancel after a few seconds.

title: `aspire update` does not cancel on ctrl+c

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

My company blocks access to `nuget.org`, instead requiring me to go through an internal proxy.  My solution has a `nuget.config` file in the root.  When trying to run `nuget update`, it hangs for a really long time before completing.

If I run with `--debug`, I can see a bunch of attempts to access nuget.org, which shouldn't happen with my nuget.config.  There is also a custom nuget.config passed in to `dotnet.exe`, which could explain why my nuget file is being ignored - `DotNetCliRunner: Running dotnet with args: package search Aspire.Hosting.AppHost --take 1000 --skip 0
--format json --configfile C:\Users\alexanderc\AppData\Local\Temp\lkmmucze.hyf\NuGet.config --prerelease`


### Expected Behavior

With my nuget.config blocking access to nuget, I wouldn't expect to see any attempt to access `nuget.org` in the `aspire update --debug` output.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Have a nuget.config explicitly removing nuget.org access
2. Run `aspire update`

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="Internal" value="https://REDACTED/nuget/index.json" />
  </packageSources>
  <packageSourceMapping>
    <clear />
    <packageSource key="Internal">
      <package pattern="*" />
    </packageSource>
  </packageSourceMapping>
</configuration>
```

### Exceptions (if any)


nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Cli `9.5.0-preview.1.25466.3+4304e9ce74ab0a02ebabb643e9c32195c1f14b16`.

`aspire update` does eventually give me a choice of the correct package upgrades to do, but it hangs on `Analyzing Project` for 20-30 secs.

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Even worse, the tool has explicitly overridden my nuget.config to add back nuget.org, which is an explicit clear violation of my company's corporate policy.  If a user has explicitly removed nuget.org from the package source list, `aspire update` should not add it back without getting confirmation from the user.

```xml
  <packageSources>
     ...
    <add key="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
  </packageSources>
  <packageSourceMapping>
    <clear />
    <packageSource key="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json">
      <package pattern="*" />
    </packageSource>
```

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
Thanks for raising the issue. For `aspire update` we've leaned pretty heavily into using it to support switching between dogfooding builds. In your scenario above were you just going from say 9.4 to 9.4.2 or something like that?

I think what we would probably need to do in your situation is set some kind of configuration entry which disables nuget updates entirely and just leave that as an exercise for you to do. Unfortunately that means that `aspire update` would be unusable for updating to preview builds because you would need to be able to add a feed to our dnceng feeds which presumably are subject to the same restrictions as nuget.org?

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
I was going from 9.4.x (I forget exactly which) to 9.5-preview in this case.  We have linked up the dnc feeds to our nuget package proxy so that the aspire preview packages will resolve from that, so for us, the packages will resolve without our default feeds.

My main thing is that I don't think `aspire update` should silently change feeds - it should ask permission, or at the very least print a message to highlight that the feeds have been updated.  Particularly in the case that someone already has specified `packageSourceMappings` - `aspire update` going and silently modifying a customer's mappings without permission I would argue is very close to being a supply chain attack.

For some context - my org's requirement is that all nuget feeds need to go through our proxy feed.  This proxy does a variety of things including 
- Evaluating package licences against corporate policy
- Checks packages for known CVE vulnerabilities
- Scans packages for malware

Effectively here, all of the package source mapping / feed configuration you'd typically see in `nuget.config` is offloaded to the proxy which handles those decisions.

title: `aspire update` ignores `nuget.config`

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

### Describe the bug

I ran `aspire update` on my project (and after working around #11453), I get build warnings when I try to `dotnet build` my project

```
S:\REDACTED.Aspire\src\REDACTED.Aspire.AppHost\REDACTED.Aspire.AppHost.csproj : warning MSB4240: Multiple versions of the same SDK "Aspire.AppHost.Sdk" cannot be specified. The previous
ly resolved SDK version "9.4.0" from location "S:\REDACTED.Aspire\src\REDACTED.Aspire.AppHost.Tests\REDACTED.Aspire.AppHost.Tests.csproj" will be used and the version "9.5.0-preview.1.2
5466.3" will be ignored.
```

_No response_

It think this is caused by having multiple AppHosts (or in my case an AppHost and a test project) in the same solution.  `aspire update` only updated the sdk for one project, but now msbuild gets very unhappy that there are conflicting versions across the solution.

title: `aspire update` doesn't fully upgrade sdk

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

It's common in wizard UIs to want a dropdown's options to be dependent on what was previously selected.

For example, choosing an option in `Select your country` updates `Select your city`.

### Describe the solution you'd like

1. A callback to provide a dropdown's option. Callback will also specify whether the dropdown is enabled (e.g. `Select your city` is disabled until `Select your country` has a value.
2. Some configuration that specifies what inputs the select is dependent on. The callback is executed when those inputs change
3. New input options are pushed to the dashboard/CLI

### Additional context

There is cross over between this feature and https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/11243 which wants options to be able to load while the dialog is displayed.
title: Dynamic select inputs that refresh data based on changes in other inputs

author: captainsafia
body:
Calling `aspire new` with a single-file app on a project that already contains files fails. We should probably have some sort of `--force` flag here?

```
$ aspire new
Enter the project name (aspire-11474): aspire-11474
Enter the output path: (./aspire-11474): .
📦  Using project templates version: 9.5.0-preview.1.25468.13
❌  The new project cannot be created because it would overwrite existing files in the output folder. Please remove or move the conflicting files, or choose a different location.
```

author: IEvangelist
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

When I call `aspire --version`, it obviously outputs the version - which is expected, but it would be better if it also output a clickable link under the version that navigates to the commit in GitHub.

### Describe the solution you'd like

For example, instead of:

```bash
aspire --version
9.5.0-preview.1.25468.13+d651991486f3c2fb81ea6ea7dead2fbe98260de1
```

It would output something like this:

```bash
aspire --version

Version: 9.5.0-preview.1.25468.13+d651991486f3c2fb81ea6ea7dead2fbe98260de1
Commit: https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/commit/d651991486f3c2fb81ea6ea7dead2fbe98260de1
```

Or with icons, this could even be an extra switch?

```bash
aspire --version --commit-url

🆚 Version: 9.5.0-preview.1.25468.13+d651991486f3c2fb81ea6ea7dead2fbe98260de1
🧬 Commit: https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/commit/d651991486f3c2fb81ea6ea7dead2fbe98260de1
```

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: KennethHoff
nodes.body:
I think `--version` should only show the version; it's used programmatically by other software.

`--info` could be added to show more information though.

nodes.author: sakhimpungose
nodes.body: Hi @IEvangelist, what use cases do you have in mind for such a feature?

title: Aspire CLI - `aspire version` better UX
